statement.p: Explain step by step how to find a singular value decomposition for an m \times n matrix A.
Give an example of a matrix 2 \times 2 whose eigenvalues are nonnegative but different from its singular values.

[MIT OCW] The question is about the matrix A=\mat{0 -1;4 0}
Find its eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
Solve the equation \dfrac{du}{dt} = Au starting witht the same vector u(0) at time t=0. In other words, solution u(t) is what combination of the eigenvectors of A?
Find the 3 matrices in the Singular Value Decomposition A=U\Sigma V^T in two steps. First, compute V and \Sigma using the matrix A^T A. Second, find the (orthonormal) columns of U.

ol.li: Since \det(A= \lambda I)=\lambda^2 + 4, the eigenvalues are 2i, -2i. Two associated eigenvectors are \vec{1 -2i}, \vec{1 2i}, though there are many other choices. u(0) is just the sum of these vectors.
One simply adds in the factors of e^{\lambda t} to each term, giving u(t)=e^{2it}\vec{1 -2i} + e^{-2it}\vec{1 2i}
